case_name: Krishna Prasad v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Civil appeal No. 1553 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment Order dated 10th September 1969 of Mysore High Court in I.T.R.C. No. 7 of 1968.

facts.text: Assessee was unmarried on date of partition and during relevant period i.e. year ending March 31, 1964.

facts.text: Up to assessment year 1963-64, assessee assessed in status of individual.

facts.text: For assessment year 1964-65, assessee filed return showing status as individual.

anchor.surface_text: Person has been defined in section 2 31  of the Act and includes, inter alia, an individual and a Hindu undivided family. The inherent fallacy of the case set up on behalf of the asses- see-appellant in our opinion, is that according to him a single individual can constitute a Hindu undivided family and be assessed as such.

anchor.surface_text: Family denotes a group of people related by blood or marriage. According to Shorter Oxford English Dictionary, 3rd Ed. the word Family means the group consisting of parents and their children, whether living together or not in wider sense, all those who are nearly connected by blood or affinity a persons children regarded collectively those descended or claiming descent from a common ancestor a house, kindred, lineage a race a people or group of peoples.

concepts.interpretation: Plurality of persons is an essential attribute of a family; a single person cannot constitute a family or HUF

holdings.text: Plurality of persons is an essential attribute of a family. A single person, male or female, does not constitute a family

anchor.surface_text: It would follow from the above that the word Family always signifies a group. Plurality of persons is an essential attribute of a family. A single person, male or female, does not constitute a family.

holdings.text: Under Hindu law a joint family may consist of a single male member and widows of deceased male members

anchor.surface_text: The plea that there must be at least two male members to form a Hindu undivided family as a taxable entity has no force. Under Hindu law a joint family may consist of a single male member and widows of deceased male members.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects strict two males requirement; cites Hindu law allowing single male + widows

holdings.text: the assessment in the status of a Hindu undivided family can be made only when there are two or more members of the Hindu undivided family

anchor.surface_text: One thing significant which follows from the above is that the assessment in the status of a Hindu undivided family can be made only when there are two or more members of the Hindu undivided family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from definitions of joint family and coparcenary requiring multiple members

holdings.text: The expression Hindu undivided family in the Income-tax Act is used in the sense in which a Hindu joint family is understood under the various schools of Hindu law

Arunachalwn Chattiar Ors.  1  and Gowli Buddana v. Commissioner of Income-tax Mysore  supra .

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax Madras v. Ram Ar. Ar. Veerappa Chettiar 2

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Madras v. Ram Ar. Ar. Veerappa Chettiar
precedents.cited_proposition: under the Hindu law it is not predicated of a Hindu joint family that there must be a male member. It was accordingly held that so long as the property which was originally of the joint Hindu family remains in the hands of the widows of the members of the family and is not divided among them, the joint family continues
precedents.cited_holding: so long as the property which was originally of the joint Hindu family remains in the hands of the widows of the members of the family and is not divided among them, the joint family continues

precedents.citation: Anant Bhikappa Patil v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil.  1

anchor.surface_text: Anant Bhikappa Patil v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil.  1

precedents.case_name: Anant Bhikappa Patil v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil
precedents.cited_proposition: power of a Hindu widow to adopt does not come to an end on the death of the sole surviving coparcener. Neither does it depend upon the vesting or divesting of the estate, nor can the right to adopt be defeated by partition between the coparceners. on the death of a sole surviving coparcener a Hindu joint family cannot be finally brought to an end while it is possible in nature or law to add a male member to it
precedents.cited_holding: an adopted son can claim as preferential heir the estate of any person other than his adoptive father if such estate has vested before the adoption in some heir other than the adopting mother
